div1.p: Carter reports on dengue fever in Galveston, Texas.

div1.head: Letter from Henry Rose Carter to Rupert Blue, September 10, 1918
div1.opener:
Report re dengue.
Assistant Surgeon General H.R. Carter.
OFFICE OF
MEDICAL OFFICER IN CHARGE
TREASURY DEPARTMENT
UNITED STATES
PUBLIC HEALTH SERVICE
Galveston, Texas.
September 10, 1918.
The Surgeon General,
U.S. Public Health Service,
Washington, D. C.
Sir:-
div1.p:
As directed by Bureau orders (J.C.P.) of September 3, 1918, I
have the honor to submit the following report on the outbreak of dengue
prevailing here.

1) I have seen seven patients the clinical findings of any three
of whom would have justified the diagnosis of Dengue. On none of them had
a leucocyte count been made and the diagnosis is based on the history of the
attack, such temperature records as are available and the eruption. This
was seen in four cases and there was a history of it in two of the others.
Spite of the lack of laboratory findings, which are being made, the diagnosis
is clear. The consensus of opinion as to the nature of the disease is general
among the physicians I have seen, not many I confess but men familiar with
the diseases of this section. It has been, I understand however, diagnosed
as “Spanish Influenza”. None of the cases I have seen, or heard of, had
respiratory symptoms and eruptions near or at the end of the fever, are
very common.

2) The first cases seem to have been noted about August 20. Since
then they have increased rapidly. I have heard the number to date estimated
as from 1000 to 2500. There are, however, no figures even approaching
accuracy. No deaths have been reported. It is indeed milder in its symptoms
#2
than the dengue of Porto Rico in /15.

3) The opinion among the physicians who have expressed themselves
as to its origin is that this disease came in with the transport Hancock,
among Marines from San Domingo and Haiti. The undisputed facts as to this
vessel area as follows: she arrived at Galveston August 5 with about 2200
Marines aboard, about 600 of them were from Guantanamo, the remainder from
San Domingo and Haiti. Neither this vessel nor her convoy the S/S. Yorktown
stopped for Quarantine Inspection. The men from Guantanamo were landed
here that day and are here now: About 800 of the others slept the night of
August 5, under the shed on the Mallory Dock. They went aboard and with
the rest of the men from San Domingo and Haiti, left in the ship the next
day (I understand) for Hampton Roads.

I have seen the Naval Surgeon; Kammerer, who was Surgeon in Command
for the Marines who landed here, he states that there was some Influenza aboard
among his contingent but no Dengue. That some cases of influenza came ashore
here but that this soon clobesed and that there have been no cases of Dengue
among the Marines at this camp. He says also, but not from his own knowledge,
that there were a number of cases of influenza among the Marines from San
Domingo and Haiti. He was occupied with the care of his own men.

The report of the inspection of the City Health Office was that
there were “104 sich aboard her mainly malarial” and quoted Dr. Humphreys
in charge of sick bay for this statement. This is a morbidity of nearly
5%.

I will not go into the observations and deductions of the Galveston
physicians, who ascribe this dengue to the Marines from San Domingo and
Haiti, although ther are well worth consideration because an examination
of the medical histories of the men sick aboard the Hancock and in the ports
#3
of departure should settle beyond question the fact whether there was Dengue
among these Marines or no.

That there were no cases of Dengue among the 600 men from Guan-
tanamo either aboard ship or since they have landed here (as Surgeon Kammerer
says) does not I think negative the statement of dengue among the other
Marines. If, as Dr. Kammerer further asserts, there were no mosquitoes
aboard the Hancock, dengue aboard her was not a communicable disease and
as these men marched directly out to their barracks they had not been exposed
to its infection. If however there were men, infective to mosquitoes the
800 men who slept on the dock they might well have infected mosquitoes and
them the town. I have seen both Aedes (stegomyia) calopus and C fatigave
here: the latter is quite common.

I do not write the above paragraph, as an argument for the intro-
duction of dengue from the Hancock, simply to show that the non-occurrence
of dengue among the Guantanamo Marines would not negative its existence
among their shipmates. Whether dengue existed aboard the Hancock should
be absolutely determinable by the Naval records.

I would also suggest that the Bureau determine by correspondence,
if Dengue exists in any town on the mainland of Texas or La. This may help
to determine id it entered Galveston by Sea or not. I am informed by Dr.
Wilson from Dr. Holt that he had heard of none at Houston at the time he
wrote, Thursday or Friday last.
